The Vernam Cipher is a mechanism for encrypting and decrypting data that combines the plain text with a randomly-generated secret key byte by byte to yield a cipher text. To decrypt, the cipher text is combined with the same secret key byte by byte to arrive at the plain text. More information is available at Wikipedia and the Crypto Museum:

This application is open source. That means that anybody can go look at the source code, and if they want to, use the source code in their own projects. This also means that one can look at the code and see exactly what the application is doing and verify that it is doing what it says it does (and not doing anything it shouldn\'t, like sending your unencrypted data to the NSA). I don\'t trust any security/privacy related application that isn\'t open source, and you shouldn\'t either.

Please note that the source code has not been audited by an independent third party. If you or your organisation are interested in performing an audit, please contact me, my email address may be found at the bottom of this page.

This app allows you to create and share secret keys, then encrypt and decrypt messages using the Vernam Cipher and deliver them using the sharing capabilities of your device.

This implementation of the Vernam cipher consumes part of the key when it is used. This means that once you encrypt or decrypt something with a key, the part of the key that is used is discarded. If this is not done and multiple encrypted messages are captured by an adversary, it may be possible for them to (partially) decrypt the messages. If, however, key data is only used once and discarded after use, decrypting messages without the secret key is impossible.

This means that you must take special care to ensure that the key(s) that you share with your communication partner(s) are used in sync. It is recommended, then, that you have two secret keys for each communications partner. One key should be used by you to encrypt messages for your recipient, and another key should be used by them to encrypt messages for you (and by you to decrypt messages from them).
This also means that a received message may not be decrypted twice, as the first decryption discards the key data needed to decrypt a second time.
This app allows you to create and share secret keys, then encrypt and decrypt messages using the Vernam Cipher and deliver them using the sharing capabilities of your device.
Wherever you see a question mark button in the title bar you may tap on it to get help for the screen you are in.

Secret keys are used to encrypt and decrypt messages. The same key must be used to encrypt and decrypt the message, so before you encrypt and send a message, you must share the key with your intended recipient.

To create a key, tap the add button on the main screen, then tap the \'New secret key\' button. Select the key length, enter or generate an optional password, and give the key an optional colour and description.

Once you have created a key, it will be shown in your list of secret keys. To share it, press and hold on the key in the list until the title bar changes to indicate it is selected. Tap the share button, then tap the mechanism you\'d like to share the key with. Android Beam is an excellent way to share secret keys.

If someone shares a key with you (via email, for example), you may open the key with the \'Import Vernam Cipher key\' app to import it into your secret key list. You may give it an optional description & colour.
Messages that you have saved are shown in the messages list. You may tap on a message to view it or long-press on it to share or delete it.
Once you have shared your key with someone, you may write them a message. Tap on the secret key to begin writing a message using that key.

When you receive an encrypted message (via an email attachment, for example), you may open the encrypted message with the \'Decrypt with Vernam Cipher\' app. This will allow you to read and optionally save the message.

You may also receive encrypted messages as text. To decrypt messages received as text, first select the text in whichever app you received it. If you are running Android Marshmallow or later, you may then tap the \'Share\' button that appears. If not, copy the text by tapping the \'Copy\' button, then open the Vernam Cipher app, tap the \'Add\' button on the bottom right, and tap the \'Decrypt clipboard\' button.

The decrypted content of the selected message is shown on this screen. If the message you are reading has just been decrypted, you may save the message plaintext; you may also share the message plaintext. If a message is not saved or shared in some way, you will not be able to view the message plaintext again.

If the save icon is visible in the action bar, the message plaintext may be saved to the device. This allows you to return and read the message again later. Any saved messages will be available to anybody that has access to your device; it is a security risk to save messages.

Tap the share icon in the action bar to share the message plaintext using the available actions on your device, such as saving the message to the clipboard or sending it to someone via email or instant messaging.

To write a message, tap in the \'Compose message\' area and begin typing. You will notice that as you type, the number of bytes remaining in the key changes. You may not write a message that is longer than the length of the key.
If the key is protected by a password, enter the password in the \'key password\' field.

IMPORTANT: The app does not attempt to distinguish a password protected key from one that is not password protected, and if you do not enter a password for a key that is password protected, the password protected key will be used without decrypting it. This will break your key.
Saving a copy of the message

If you want to save the message cleartext to your message list, check the appropriate box before sending the message. Doing so will give you the ability to go back and read your message later at the cost of security.

When you are finished writing your message, tap the send button at the top of the screen, then select how you would like to transmit the encrypted message. When you reach the point of selecting which app to use to send the message, the part of the key used to encrypt the message has been consumed.

You may send messages using the sharing capabilities of your device. You may send the encrypted message either as a file or as text. Different sharing options will be available to you depending on which sending method you use and which apps you have installed on your device.
Sending messages as files or text

Messages sent as files may be shared using applications that allow you to send files to people, such as email applications. When the recipient receives the file (in their email, for example), they may open the attachment using the \'Decrypt with Vernam Cipher\' application to decrypt the message.

Messages sent as text may be shared using applications that allow you to save or send text, such as messaging applications. When your recipient receives the text, they may decrypt the message by selecting it and sharing it with the \'Decrypt with Vernam Cipher\' application (if using Android Marshmallow or later), or by copying the text and selecting the \'Decrypt clipboard\' button within the Vernam Cipher app.

If, however, key data is only used once, decrypting messages without the secret key is impossible.
